Palladium nanoparticle decorated high nitrogen-doped graphene with high catalytic activity for Suzuki–Miyaura and Ullmann-type coupling reactions in aqueous media Siyavash Kazemi Movahed Minoo Dabiri Ayoob Bazgir ⁎ Faculty of Chemistry, Shahid Beheshti University, G.C. Tehran 1983969411, Iran Faculty of Chemistry, Shahid Beheshti University G.C. Tehran 1983969411 Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +98 21 2990 3104; fax: +98 21 2243 1661. Graphical abstract Palladium nanoparticle are decorated over a highly nitrogen-doped graphene (Pd NPs-HNG) in a facile manner by reducing palladium chloride in the presence of ethylene glycol as reducing, stabilizing, and dispersing agent. The obtained catalyst can act as an efficient catalyst for the Suzuki–Miyaura and Ullmann-type coupling reactions of a broad spectrum of aryl halides in aqueous media. The remarkable reactivity of the Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite toward Suzuki–Miyaura and Ullmann-type coupling reactions is attributed to the high degree of nitrogen loading in graphene sheets. The N-doped graphene as polycyclic heteroaromatic molecule acts as both the catalyst support and the electron source (reducing agent) for Ullmann homocoupling. The catalyst could be recovered and reused several times without a significant loss of activity. Keywords C–C coupling Heterogeneous catalysis N-doped graphene Palladium nanoparticle. 1 Introduction Aryl–aryl bond formation is one of the most important tools of modern organic synthesis. These bonds are very often found in commercial dyes, natural products, and organic conductors or semiconductors as well as the backbone of some ligands for asymmetric catalysis [1]. Various nanoparticle-based heterogeneous or semi-heterogeneous catalysts such as palladium nanoparticles in ionic liquids, polymers, organic–inorganic fluorinated hybrid materials, and glass–polymer composite materials as well as on common inorganic substrates, including carbon materials, silica, alumina, or zeolites have been described in literature for aryl–aryl coupling reactions, e.g., Suzuki–Miyaura, and Ullmann reactions [2–5]. Although, the heterogeneous supports allow efficient recycling, a decrease in the activity of the immobilized catalysts is frequently observed [6]. Therefore, the development of heterogeneous palladium nanocatalysts with high activity, stability, and recyclability is an important goal of nanomaterial research. This can have a considerable impact on the future of the chemical and pharmaceutical industries in the future. Graphene has stimulated wide interest because of the properties associated with the two-dimensional (2D) crystal structure formed by sp2-hybridized carbon. Extensive studies have shown great promise for applications in fields such as electronics, sensors, batteries, super capacitors, and catalysts [7–10]. Theoretical as well as experimental studies have revealed that a doped graphene can be used to tailor its band structure, modulate electronic properties, manipulate surface chemistry, and open the band gap in graphene for device applications. Among the numerous potential dopants, nitrogen is considered as an excellent element for the chemical doping because of its similar atom size and five valence electrons available to form strong valence bonds with carbon atoms. N-dopants in the carbon skeleton can weaken the formation of “re-graphitized” carbon regions and also be usually regarded as favorable anchor sites or defects for enhancing particle nucleation and reducing the particle size [11–14]. At the same time, it was disclosed that introduction of nitrogen can modify the electronic structure of the carbon matrix, strengthening the interaction between carbon and guest molecules [15,16]. This endow carbon with a metal-like “d” band electronic structure to host the reactive species due to its high charge and spin density caused by the adjacent nitrogen [17]. Based on the above introduction and also a part of our ongoing studies in the synthesis of graphene nanocomposite catalysts for cross- and homo-coupling reactions [18,19], herein, we report a novel protocol for the Suzuki–Miyaura and Ullmann-type coupling reaction by palladium nanoparticles-high N-doped graphene (Pd NPs-HNG) nanocomposite in aqueous solution under aerobic conditions. Additionally, the effects of solvent polarity, base, and temperature on yield, and recycling potential of the catalyst have all been assessed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Characterization All chemicals were purchased from commercial suppliers and all solvents were purified and dried using standard procedures. IR spectra were recorded on a Bomem MB-Series FT-IR spectrophotometer. Diffraction data were collected on a STOE STADI P with scintillation detector, secondary monochromator, and Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5406Å). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed using a Gammadata-scienta ESCA 200 hemispherical analyzer equipped with an Al Kα (1486.6eV) X-ray source. Raman spectra of GO, HNG, and Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite were recorded on a Bruker SENTERR (2009) with an excitation beam wavelength at 785nm. Scanning electron microscope images and EDX mapping of Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite were obtained on a Philips XL-30 ESEM electron microscope. Transmission electron microscope images of HNG, Pd NPs-RGO, Pd NPs-NG, and Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposites were taken using Philips CM-30 transmission electron microscope with an accelerating voltage of 150kV and Zeiss EM10C transmission electron microscope with an accelerating voltage of 80kV. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a BRUKERDRX-300 AVANCE spectrometer. NMR spectra were obtained in DMSO-d 6 using TMS as internal standard. Melting points of products were measured on an Elecrtothermal 9100 apparatus and are uncorrected. The concentration of palladium was estimated using Shimadzu AA-680 flame atomic absorption spectrophotometer and inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) Varian Vista PRO Radial. Elemental analysis of HNG and NG nanocomposites were performed using an Elementar Analysen system GmbH VarioEL CHNS. Gas chromatography was performed on a Trace GC ultra from the Thermo Company equipped with FID detector and Rtx®-1 capillary column. 2.2 Preparation of graphene oxide (GO) The graphite powder (2.5g) was first treated with a mixture of 12.5mL of concentrated H2SO4 with 2.5g of K2S2O8 and 2.5g of P2O5. The mixture was kept at 80°C for 6h. Subsequently, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and diluted with 500mL of deionized (DI) water and left overnight. The mixture was then filtered and washed with DI water to remove the residual acid. The product was dried under ambient conditions overnight. The pre-oxidized graphite was then subjected to oxidation by Hummers's method. The pretreated graphite powder was put into cold (0°C) concentrated H2SO4 (125mL). Then KMnO4 (15g) was added gradually under stirring, and the temperature of the mixture was kept below 20°C by cooling. The mixture was then stirred at 35°C for 4h and then diluted with DI water (250mL). Because adding water to concentrated sulfuric acid medium releases a large amount of heat, the dilution was carried out in an ice bath to keep the temperature below 50°C. After adding all of the 250mL DI water, the mixture was stirred for 2h, and then an additional 750mL DI water was added. Shortly thereafter, 20mL of 30% H2O2 was added to the mixture and the color of the mixture changed into brilliant yellow and began bubbling. The mixture was filtered and washed with 0.1M HCl to remove metal ions, followed by 500mL DI water to remove the acid, and then was dialyzed against DI water. The resulting GO solid was dried in air [20,21]. 2.3 Preparation of high nitrogen-doped graphene (HNG) Aqueous dispersion solution of GO (10mL, 40mg) was diluted with 25mL of deionized water, and then urea (12g) was added into the GO dispersion under sonication for 3h. After that, the solution was sealed in a 50mL of Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 180°C for 12h. The solids (N-doped graphene sheets) were filtered and washed several times with distilled water. Finally, the sample was collected and dried in a vacuum oven at 80°C [22]. The nitrogen loading was determined to be 11.24wt% by elemental analysis (CHN). 2.4 Preparation of palladium nanoparticle-high nitrogen-doped graphene (Pd NPs-HNG) About 40mg of HNG was dispersed in 40mL of a mixture of ethylene glycol (EG) and deionized (DI) water (3:1) by ultrasonication for 1h and followed by stirring for 12h. Further, PdCl2 (7.3mg) was added under mechanically stirred conditions for 24h. The pH of the entire solution was adjusted to 11 by NaOH (2.5M), and the solution was refluxed at 110°C for 7h to ensure complete reduction of Pd. Finally, the suspension was filtered and the solid washed with deionized water repeatedly until filtrated solution became neutral and then dried in vacuum oven at 50°C [23]. The loading of palladium was measured to be 0.80mmolg−1 by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES). 2.5 Preparation of nitrogen-doped graphene (NG) The pH of aqueous dispersion of GO (70mL, 140mg) was adjusted at 10 using 30% ammonia. Then 2mL of hydrazine hydrate was added with the magnetically stirring for 10min. The solution was then transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 80°C for 3h. The reduced graphene sheets were collected with centrifugation, followed by washing several times with deionized water and then dried in vacuum oven at 50°C [24]. The nitrogen loading was determined to be 3.2wt% by elemental analysis (CHN). 2.6 Preparation of palladium nanoparticle-nitrogen-doped graphene (Pd NPs-NG) About 40mg of NG was dispersed in 40mL of a mixture of ethylene glycol (EG) and deionized water (3:1) by ultrasonication for 1h and followed by stirring for 12h. Further, PdCl2 (7.3mg) was added under mechanically stirred conditions for 24h. The pH of the entire solution was adjusted to 11 by NaOH (2.5M), and then the solution was refluxed at 110°C for 7h to ensure complete reduction of Pd. Finally, the suspension was filtered and the solid washed with deionized water repeatedly until filtrated solution became neutral and then dried in vacuum oven at 50°C. The loading of palladium was measured to be 0.74mmolg−1 by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES). 2.7 Preparation of reduced graphene oxide (RGO) GO (0.6g) was dispersed in 100mL of deionized water. Then, NaBH4 (1.0g) was gradually added and the mixture was heated at 100°C for 24h. The resulted precipitation was centrifuged, repeatedly washed with deionized water and ethanol. The final product was dried in vacuum oven at 80°C overnight [25]. 2.8 Preparation of palladium nanoparticle-reduced graphene oxide (Pd NPs-RGO) About 40mg of RGO was dispersed in 40mL of a mixture of ethylene glycol (EG) and deionized water (3:1) by ultrasonication for 1h and followed by stirring for 12h. Further, the PdCl2 (7.3mg) was added under mechanically stirred conditions for 24h. The pH of the entire solution was adjusted to 11 by NaOH (2.5M), and the solution was refluxed at 110°C for 7h to ensure complete reduction of Pd. Finally, the suspension was filtered and the solid washed with deionized water repeatedly until filtrated solution became neutral and then dried in vacuum oven at 50°C. The loading of palladium was measured to be 0.69mmolg−1 by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES). 2.9 General procedure for the Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reaction A mixture of Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite (0.025–0.1mol% of Pd), K2CO3 (3mmol), aryl halide (1.0mmol), aryl boronic acid (1.3mmol), and EtOH/H2O (2mL, 1:1) was stirred in air at 60°C. After completion of the reaction as indicated by TLC, the heterogeneous mixture was cooled to room temperature and filtered through a pad of celite. The filtrate was concentrated and then the residue was purified by thin-layer chromatography (ethyl acetate and n-hexane) to yield a pure product. The catalyst was recovered by filtration and washed extensively with acetone and drying in the air. 2.10 General procedure for the Ullmann homo-coupling reaction A mixture of Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite (0.25–2mol% of Pd), K3PO4 (3mmol), aryl halide (1.0mmol), and 2mL of H2O was stirred in air at 100°C. After completion of the reaction as indicated by TLC, the heterogeneous mixture was cooled to room temperature and filtered through a pad of celite. The filtrate was concentrated and then the residue was purified by thin-layer chromatography (ethyl acetate and n-hexane) to yield a pure product. The catalyst was recovered by filtration and washed extensively with acetone and drying in the air. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of catalyst The process for the preparation of Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite is schematically described in Scheme 1 . The N-doped graphene with high nitrogen content (11.24wt% of N) were synthesized through a one-pot hydrothermal process using urea as the chemical dopant in the presence of graphene oxide (GO) aqueous dispersion [22]. Then, the decoration of Pd NPs was carried out on HNG by a modified polyol reduction technique [23]. Raman spectroscopy is a very useful tool for investigating the electronic and phonon structure graphene-based materials [26]. The Raman spectra of prepared GO, HNG, and Pd NPs-HNG are shown in Fig. 1 . The characteristic D and G bands of carbon materials are observed around 1285 and 1570cm−1, respectively. The D band is characteristic of a breathing mode for k-point phonons of A1g, while the G band is the result of the first-order scattering of the E2g mode of sp2 carbon domains [27]. Both bands can be influenced by doping [28]. The D band is significantly enhanced in HNG with respect to GO because pyridinic and pyrrolic nitrogens are accompanied by defects inside the graphene network and functional edges of graphene sheets [29,30]. The G band of HNG shifts to the higher frequency (8.77cm−1) with respect to that of graphene oxide. Previous theoretical simulations on N-doped carbon nanotubes suggest that substitution of carbon atoms with graphitic nitrogen was n-type doping, while pyridinic and pyrrolic nitrogens were of p-type doping [31,33]. Because HNG contains more pyridinic and pyrrolic nitrogens, G band shift in HNG is in agreement with the earlier observation upshift in p-type doped graphite and carbon nanotubes [34,35]. In addition, a small shoulder appears for the Pd NPs-HNG at the higher wavenumbers along with the G-band. This is known as the D’ band. The origin of this band is attributed to the interaction of localized vibration modes of impurities (or dopants) with the extended phonon modes of graphene being responsible for the G-band [23]. After conjugation of the Pd NPs onto the HNG sheets, the G-band is observed to shift further toward higher wavenumbers (3.95cm−1). The intensity ratio of G-band and D-band (ID/IG) is a general parameter, reflecting the carbon hybridization state of materials and the degree of disorder [36]. As shown, after the hydrothermal synthesis of GO with urea, the ID/IG was 1.58 for the resulting HNG, while the ID/IG of GO was 1.49. The higher value of ID/IG observed with HNG clearly demonstrates the heteroatomic doping of nitrogen into the graphene frame and the enhanced degree of disorder [36]. The ID/IG decreases to 1.35 for the Pd NPs-HNG, possibly as a result of the Pd NPs growth at the defective regions on the HNG surface [37]. Nitrogen doping of graphene can help in enhancing the palladium binding to the defected sites on the adsorbent, thereby lowering the possibility of metal−metal cohesion [23]. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of GO, HNG, and Pd NPs-HNG are illustrated in Fig. 2 . The GO peak at 2θ =10.9° corresponds to a d-spacing of 0.81nm resulting from the insertion of hydroxyl and epoxy groups between the graphite sheets as a result of the oxidation process of graphite [38]. However, the peak at 2θ =10.9° entirely collapsed after hydrothermal reaction, and a broad diffraction peak around 25° of the graphite (002) plane was observed for the synthesized HNG sample, indicating the framework of the reduced sample was composed of few-layer stacked graphene sheets [39]. Besides, the interlayer distance was reduced from 0.81nm of GO to 0.35nm of HNG, which certified the recovery of the π-conjugated system after the reduction of GO [19]. In the XRD pattern of the Pd NPs-HNG, the peaks at around 2θ =39.75°, 46.18°, 67.62° can be assigned to the (111), (200), (220) crystalline planes of the face center cubic (fcc) structure of palladium (JCPDS No. 87-0643), respectively. Also, an additional broad diffraction peak appears at 2θ =25° which can be indexed to the disordered HNG sheets. The electronic property of Pd NPs–HNG nanocomposite was probed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. As shown in Fig. 3a, the peaks corresponding to C 1s, N 1s, O 1s, and Pd 3 s, 3p and 3d was clearly observed in the XPS survey spectrum. The C 1s peak of Pd NPs-HNG is shown in Fig. 3b. The main peak at 284.31eV is associated with the C–C, implying that most of the carbon atoms in the Pd NPs-HNG are arranged in a conjugated honeycomb lattice [22]. Additionally, the other two peaks located at 285.35 and 287.87eV are ascribed to C=N and C–N, respectively. From the N 1s XPS scan shown in Fig. 3c, it is observed that three different types of nitrogen are present in the Pd NPs-HNG system, namely pyridinic nitrogen (397.02eV, 5.01%), pyrrolic nitrogen (399.10eV, 71.21%), and graphitic nitrogen (401.14eV, 23.78%) [22]. The pyridinic and pyrrolic nitrogen atoms are present in abundance as compared to the graphitic nitrogen and donate one and two p-electrons to the graphene sheet, respectively [22]. From XPS analysis, it is observed that the content of pyrrolic nitrogen is more in the Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite. The Pd0 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 peaks are observed at 335.48 and 340.83eV, respectively (Fig. 3d). Palladium in the oxidation state of II is also detected (peaks at 337.58 and 342.99eV). The absence of chlorine in the XPS spectrum of the Pd NPs–HNG nanocomposite corroborates that this higher oxidation state of Pd is due to the formation of Pd−O bond or Pd−N bond [40] not that of PdCl2. The high-resolution scan from 528 to 540eV reveals the presence of O 1s (531.87eV), Pd 3p3/2 (533.83eV), and Pd-O or Pd-N 3p3/2 (536.42eV) peaks in the order of their percentage contribution (Fig. 3e) [23]. Fig. 4a depicts the SEM micrograph of the Pd NPs-HNG sample. Several graphene layers and folds in their planes are visible. The density and distribution of elements the N and Pd on the Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite are evaluated by quantitative energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscope (EDS) mapping. As it can be seen in Fig. 4b and c, Pd only located at the edges of N-doped graphene sheets, and N and Pd elements are uniformly dispersed on the entire surface of Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite. Fig. 4d and e shows a comparison between the morphologies of NG and Pd NPs-HNG, as investigated by TEM. The micrograph of HNG possesses similar wrinkled sheet morphology (Fig. 4d). As Fig. 4e shows, the surfaces of HNG are covered with good dispersion of Pd NPs with an average size of ∼15nm. The TEM micrographs of Pd NPs-RGO and Pd NPs-NG (Fig. S1a–c and d–f) show large size (∼50nm) and small size (∼5nm) palladium, respectively. The TEM micrographs also show agglomerate Pd particles supported on the reduced graphene oxide, and nitrogen-doped graphene sheets. A comparison between Fig. S1 and Fig. 4d revealed that dispersion of NPs is excellent in the high nitrogen-doped graphene. Some of the agglomeration of Pd NPs in Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite may be due to the incorporation, which affects the nucleation of Pd NP [41]. This is attributed to the fact that the N-doping creates a defective topology in the graphene network, which then act as nucleation sites for the Pd particle to get attached during the modified polyol synthesis method [23]. Additionally, Pd NPs are not found outside the NG sheets. 4 The catalytic activity of Pd NPs–HNG nanocomposite toward the Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reaction The catalytic activity of the Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite was then tested in the Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reaction. We chose the coupling between 1-iodo-4-methylbenzene and phenyl boronic acid as a model reaction in EtOH:H2O (1:1) as solvent at 60°C in the presence of KOH as base and with a catalyst loading of 0.025mol% of Pd. Under this condition, we found that the cross-coupling reaction proceeded well, affording the promising moderate yields (38%) of the corresponding biaryl (Table 1 , entry 1). Various bases such as K3PO4, Cs2CO3, and K2CO3 were also screened for their effect on the reaction in EtOH:H2O (1:1) as solvent at 60°C. A superior yield obtained when K2CO3 was used as the base (Table 1, entries 1–4). Then, different solvents were screened in the model reaction using K2CO3 as the base (Table 1, entries 5–7). It was found that the reaction using EtOH:H2O (1:1) after 2.5h resulted in a higher yield. Additionally, in order to investigate the effect of the nitrogen loading, we used Pd NPs-NG and Pd NPs-RGO in the model reaction. The observed yields of biaryl in both cases were remarkably inferior (Table 1, entries 8 and 9). It is well known that the activity of Pd-supported catalysts depends dramatically on the metal dispersion and the particle size. In particular, C–C bond coupling reactions such as Suzuki reaction are very demanding from the point of view of palladium particle size [42]. Probably for this reason, the activity of Pd NPs supported on NG and HNG sheets are higher than that of Pd NPs supported on RGO. Additionally, an increase in the nitrogen loading in graphene sheet leads to an increase in the biphenyl yield. Probably, the nitrogen atoms in the graphene sheets can act as a ligand for Pd NPs. Notably, base-free reaction and the reaction using the pristine HNG without any Pd NPs gave no conversion in the present system under the same reaction conditions (Table 1, entries 10 and 11). With the optimized reaction conditions in hand, we next managed to examine the scope and limitation of Suzuki reaction with various types of aryl halides derivatives and aryl boronic acids (Table 2 ). It can be seen from Table 2 that the Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reaction with most substrates preceded in good yields. Aryl bromides and iodides bearing electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups reacted well and giving good yields. The hindered substrates such as 2-iodotoluene and 2-iodo-1,3,5-trimethylbenzene converted into the corresponding products with a moderate yield (Table 2, entries 3 and 4). Unfortunately, the catalytic system was less effective for the reaction of aryl chlorides and moderate yields were obtained in the presence of tetra butyl ammonium bromide (TBAB) (Table 2, entries 10–12). 4.1 Reusability of Pd NPs-HNG in Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reaction The reusability of the Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite was examined in the Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reaction of phenyl boronic acid with phenyl iodide. It was found that the recovery can be successfully achieved in five successive reaction runs (Table 3 ). The heterogeneous nature of the catalysis was proved using a hot filtration test and atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) analysis. To determine whether the catalyst is actually functioning in a heterogeneous manner or whether it is merely a reservoir for more active soluble palladium species, we performed a hot filtration test in the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction of phenyl boronic acid with phenyl iodide after ∼50% of the coupling reaction is completed. The hot filtrates were then transferred to another flask containing K2CO3 (3equiv.) in EtOH:H2O (1:1) (2mL) at 60°C. Upon further heating of catalyst-free solution for 4h, no considerable progress (∼4% by GC analysis) was observed. Moreover, using AAS of the same reaction solution at the midpoint of completion indicated that no significant quantities of palladium are lost to the reaction liquors during the process. 5 The catalytic activity of Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite toward the Ullmann homo-coupling reaction Finally, diverse symmetrical biphenyls were synthesized in high yields via reductive homo-couplings of aryl halides using Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite without any external reductant. To optimize the reaction conditions, iodobenzene was selected as a model substrate in the presence of various bases (Table 4 , entries 1-6). By using water as the solvent at 100°C with a catalyst loading of 0.25mol% of Pd, a superior yield was obtained when K3PO4 was used as the base (Table 4, entry 3). Additionally, the Pd NPs-NG and Pd NPs-RGO were tested in the model reaction and yields of biphenyl in both cases were remarkably lower (Table 4, entries 7 and 8). The base-free reaction and the reaction using the pristine HNG without any Pd NPs gave no conversion in the present system under the same reaction conditions (entries 9–10). Notably, the side products benzene or phenol did not form in all of experiments, which results from dehalogenation or hydrodehalogenation of Ph–I, respectively. The hydrodehalogenation product obtained from the complete quenching of the reaction due to the lower stability of Pd NPs [43]. Further investigations of the efficiency and scope of the method were performed, and the results are summarized in Table 5 . The Pd NPs-HNG was proved to be a very active catalyst for the homo-coupling of a broad spectrum of aryl halides. As illustrated in Table 5, both electron-donating (Table 5, entries 2 and 3) and electron-withdrawing (Table 5, entries 4 and 5) aryl iodides were coupled cleanly to provide the corresponding biaryls in good to excellent yields. Aryl iodide with meta-substituent delivered the corresponding biaryl in good yield (Table 5, entry 4), showing that the steric hindrance played little effect in the formation of intermediate aryl-palladium complexes [44]. In the case of aryl bromides and chlorides, good to excellent biaryl yields were obtained after the prolongation of reaction times and the increase in the amount of palladium to 2mol% (Table 5, entries 7-13). It should be noted that the desired biaryls were delivered in good yields in the Pd NPs-HNG catalytic system without the reduction of nitro or carbonyl groups (Table 2, entries 4-5, 8, and 12-13). The by-products from hydrodechlorination of the chloroarenes with electron-withdrawing groups in homo-coupling reaction were also obtained in some cases [45]. Notably, it was proved that Pd NPs-HNG exhibited excellent catalytic activity and selectivity for the Ullmann homo-coupling of these substrates, and no hydrodechlorination products were observed under the investigated conditions (Table 5, entries 10-13). The external reducing agents such as ethanol [46], formate salts [47], glucose [48], hydrogen gas [49], or zinc [50] are used for Ullmann homo-coupling. Recently, Karimi et al. reported Pd@IFMC as a catalyst for Ullmann homo-coupling reaction without any chemical and stoichiometric co-reducing agents [51]. We believed N-doped graphene as polycyclic heteroaromatic molecule acts as both the catalyst support and the electron source (reducing agent). This feature is demonstrated previously for polyaniline nanofiber [52]. Although, an increase in the nitrogen loading in graphene sheet leads to an increase biphenyl yield that an indicated nitrogen-bonding configuration in graphene sheets plays the key role in the Ullmann homo-coupling. 5.1 Reusability of Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite in Ullmann homo-coupling reaction The reusability of the Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite was examined in the Ullmann homo-coupling reaction of phenyl iodide. It was found that the recovery can be successfully achieved in five successive reaction runs (Table 6 ). XPS analysis of Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite after the 6th run revealed the presence high concentration of K and P, which may suggest that some base remains attached to the surface of the solid (Fig. 5 ). This observation may be due to the adsorption of residual K3PO4 to the HNG surface, which avoided the need of further addition in the subsequent experiments. The TEM micrographs of Pd NPs-HNG recycled after 6th run shows the surfaces of HNG are covered with good dispersion of Pd NPs with an average size of ∼12nm (Fig. 6 ). 6 Conclusion In conclusion, we demonstrated that palladium nanoparticles supported on high nitrogen-doped graphene are a highly active catalyst for Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling of a range of aryl halides. Moreover, we have shown this nanocomposite as competent catalysts for the Ullmann homo-couplings of different aryl halides to afford symmetrical biaryls in excellent yields without any chemical and stoichiometric co-reducing agents. It was found that when the loading the nitrogen increases from 0% to 3.2 and 11.2wt%, the biphenyl yields increase from 38 to 69% and 98%, respectively, that an indicated nitrogen-bonding configuration in graphene sheets plays the key role in the Ullmann homo-coupling. We believed N-doped graphene as polycyclic heteroaromatic molecule acts as both the catalyst support and the electron source (reducing agent) for Ullmann homocoupling. Leaching tests such as hot filtration test and AAS analysis indicate that the catalytic reaction is mainly heterogeneous in nature. The reusability of this catalyst is high, and the catalyst can be reused several times without a significant decrease in its catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: Palladium nanoparticle are decorated over a highly nitrogen-doped graphene (Pd NPs-HNG) in a facile manner by reducing palladium chloride in the presence of ethylene glycol as reducing, stabilizing, and dispersing agent. The obtained catalyst can act as an efficient catalyst for the Suzuki–Miyaura and Ullmann-type coupling reactions of a broad spectrum of aryl halides in aqueous media. The remarkable reactivity of the Pd NPs-HNG nanocomposite toward Suzuki–Miyaura and Ullmann-type coupling reactions is attributed to the high degree of nitrogen loading in graphene sheets. The N-doped graphene as polycyclic heteroaromatic molecule acts as both the catalyst support and the electron source (reducing agent) for Ullmann homocoupling. The catalyst could be recovered and reused several times without a significant loss of activity.
coredata.dc:title: Palladium nanoparticle decorated high nitrogen-doped graphene with high catalytic activity for Suzuki–Miyaura and Ullmann-type coupling reactions in aqueous media
